text: the finance tutorial is is a course
that's web-based and intended to cover
the basics of corporate finance one of
its primary uses here at Harvard
Business School is going to be as a pre
matriculation course we're going to ask
students to go through this course
before they arrive on campus to begin
the MBA program one of the things that
we did in developing this product was
take advantage of the experience of the
team that created it in creating prior
products i think as as we create more
and more of them we get better and
better at it and the development team
was really excited to try some new
things with the finance course those
included the retro animation the look
and feel of at the color palette we
tried to unify with the pace that we
were taking with the the vocabulary we
were using and really have it come
together so that it felt like a unified
whole something that that had the same
look and feel and the same light touch
whether you're at the beginning of it
the middle out at the end of it whether
you are high in the process or low in
the process and I think it came together
really nicely I almost never am able to
go through it myself without a smile
because I just like the way it looks the
teaching intent is to cover the basic
principles associated with finance at an
introductory level basic principles and
then I would also say some of the basic
tools so ratio analysis risk and return
discounted cash flows time value of
money those types of tools that are
really common currency in the corporate
finance world but not necessarily common
currency outside that world and so
getting people introduced to those is an
important mission of the of the product
the other thing that I think it does
very well is engage students so that
they interact with it sometimes when I
describe it I tell people well if a
picture's worth a thousand words then a
moving picture or an interactive picture
is worth 10,000 or 100,000 words well
one of the things that we do by creating
a product like this and putting it out
there before the students even arrive on
campus is we're telling them that we
care about how they how they like to
learn we're
attention to what they're telling us in
Prior cohorts and we care about how they
feel when they get here so we're willing
to make an investment in that I think it
also tells the the broader educational
world that that Harvard is trying to
keep up is keeping up with what's new
not only in the realm of technology but
in the realm of pulling those
technologies not necessarily are not
always into the classroom but into the
educational arena and seeing what we can
do with them it's very exciting to
experiment with them
